Look at these great tools by @MattHodges and @mauforonda. They generate regular #digests of popular #mastodon posts from your timeline in case you missed anything. Looking forward to trying them out! 😍

- #python code base: https://github.com/hodgesmr/mastodon_digest
- personal digest page: https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_digest
- email digest: https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_email_digest
- link collector: https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_links

Examples are available from the respective github.io pages.

title: Muse: Text-To-Image Generation via Masked Generative Transformers

last_post.content:
RT @nathanbenaich@twitter.com

Bye bye diffusion, hello latte art!

This is impressive, fast, and efficient.

Muse is a text-to-image Transformer model that achieves SOTA image generation performance while being significantly more efficient than diffusion or autoregressive models.

https://muse-model.github.io

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/nathanbenaich/status/1610573440968179712

title: US National Science Foundation looks to shake up funding with ‘Golden Ticket’ pilot

last_post.content:
Yes!

US National Science Foundation looks to shake up funding with ‘Golden Ticket’ pilot

The agency wants to give individual reviewers the power to fund proposals they think are promising, even if other panelists disagree. The aim is to avoid only backing the least controversial applications

title: https://amzn.to/3GA2HUz

last_post.content:
Hey friends - I am in Antarctica with extremely slow and limited internet and I have a book coming out this year that I'd normally be posting more about because pre-orders are *critical* to a book's success.

Help me get the word out?

OUT THERE: THE SCIENCE BEHIND SCI-FI FILM AND TV

From black holes to space elevators and extraterrestrial civilizations, this is a rich and beautifully illustrated book for your coffee table. And astronaut Mae Jemison wrote the Foreword!

https://amzn.to/3GA2HUz

#Harvard is hiring a University Scholarly Communication Officer and Director of Open Scholarship and Research Data Services.
https://sjobs.brassring.com/TGnewUI/Search/home/HomeWithPreLoad?partnerid=25240&siteid=5341&PageType=JobDetails&jobid=1980218#jobDetails=1980218_5341

I was the director of the Office for Scholarly Communication. When I stepped down (semi-retired) last year, Harvard restructured the office and this job ad shows the results. Subscribe to support my work.

title: https://joinmastodon.org/covenant

last_post.content:
I have become anecdotally aware of several (smaller) mastodon instances that are considering shutting down because they cannot afford their server bills.

If you are a #mastodonadmin of an instance that is 1000+ users and considering shutting down please reach out to me.

We may be willing to take over your instance and save your users if you are compliant with the Mastodon Server Covenenant (https://joinmastodon.org/covenant)

title: Remembering Martin Ravallion

last_post.content: Remembering Martin Ravallion (who sadly died on December 24): Berk Ozler and I offer some reflections on his work, how he helped both of us join the World Bank, why him not hiring me in his unit may have been the best gift he ever gave me, his surprising early career switch, and more . https://blogs.worldbank.org/impactevaluations/remembering-martin-ravallion

title: ‘Disruptive’ science has declined — and no one knows why

last_post.content:
I don't necessarily disagree with this take.

But there does seem to me to also be the possibility that most of the low-hanging fruit got picked. If our model of the world is roughly right within the parameters we normally operate, there won't be many radical disruptions.

RT @eric_mccorkle@twitter.com

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-04577-5

Alright... I'm coming out of Twitter retirement to unload on this.

We know damn well why.

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/eric_mccorkle/status/1611158610532528128

last_post.content: TikTok's algorithm is like the formula for Coca Cola: widely believed to be the secret sauce behind the product's success, but in fact quite ordinary. title: Nazi Germany Used Honorary Consuls to Advance Agenda Globally, Records Show

last_post.content:
Nazi Germany Used Honorary Consuls to Advance Agenda Globally, Records Show
--
ProPublica & ICIJ used declassified intelligence documents and media accounts to ID about 20 honorary consuls suspected of supporting the Third Reich through espionage & other illicit activities.

They largely lived & worked in neutral countries in Latin America, Europe & Africa, where Nazis sought to cultivate allies or gain an advantage.

https://www.propublica.org/article/shadow-diplomats-nazi-germany-spies-honorary-consuls

title: http://butterurls.com/

last_post.content:
Before I share any URLs with friends, I manually remove any UTM codes/tracking data and replace them with "=butts".

This has been a time consuming process in the past, but not anymore!!!!

BUTTER is a new Chrome extension that cleans any unwanted code from a URL before you share it... and replaces that code with "butts".

Use it for the lulz. Use it for your privacy. Use it to make the web a weirder place!

http://butterurls.com/ #chrome #extension #butts

title: Petals – Decentralized platform for running 100B+ language models

last_post.content: it annoys me that applications of large language models continue to depend on big-company centralized computing infrastructure, even as text-to-image models become more locally runnable. this looks like an interesting potential (stopgap?) solution: a BitTorrent-style swarm in which each participating machine hosts a small chunk of the full model, enabling distributed inference + fine-tuning https://petals.ml

title: COVID Data Tracker

last_post.content: - XBB.1.5 is surging very rapidly, having increased 10x from 4% of US cases to 41% in just three weeks (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions). It grew out of NY and has become predominant in the northeast US, and experts predict it will spread across the US in the coming weeks. In the past two years, the first week of January was the peak of holiday surges, but this year, it appears we'll see increased transmission and risks throughout January.

title: The Work of Martin Ravallion: A Round-up of Influential Research from an Exceptional Poverty Economist

last_post.content:
The year 2022 ended on a sad note with the passing of Martin Ravallion, one of the most influential economists working to measure (and reduce) poverty around.

If you’re just learning of Ravallion’s work, here’s a micro-summary of each of his 15 most cited (per year since publication) articles.

https://www.cgdev.org/blog/work-martin-ravallion-round-influential-research-exceptional-poverty-economist

Rest in peace, Professor Ravallion. My gratitude goes out to you for your leadership and your research.

title: https://icymilaw.org/about/

last_post.content:
Thx @IntlLawGnome

FWIW, @icymi_law is explicitly billed as an opt-in algorithmic feed for non-tech folks designed to address the discovery problem. Also, its workflow/algo choices are made clear on the associated site: https://icymilaw.org/about/

It has grown to include a digest on that site, part of which is a collection of preprints (made easy by the fact law folks all use one preprint server). It also collects hashtags.

title: Why do economists so dislike "conditional independence"?

last_post.content: Interesting post by Scott Cunningham on how conditional independence goes against rationality (people choosing the treatment based on expected benefits) and that's why economists don't like this assumption: https://causalinf.substack.com/p/why-do-economists-so-dislike-conditional Perhaps a corollary might be that selection on observables then becomes more plausible when the "treatment" is not something you choose based on a rational calculation but instead is something like a feeling or a personality trait or some aspect of your environment.

title: Facebook Wanted Out of Politics. It Was Messier Than Anyone Expected.

last_post.content:
There are two pieces of news in this one:

https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-politics-controls-zuckerberg-meta-11672929976?mod=tech_lead_pos2
 
1.     In late 2021, with zero fanfare, Facebook began changing newsfeed worldwide to exclude comments and reshares in how it promotes politics, societal and health-related content.

2.     This wasn’t enough for FB’s leadership and board. Late in 2021, they asked Facebook to move forward with zero-weighting ALL civic content in newsfeed. Facebook wanted out of politics.

title: Republican Party Stumbles Through the Wilderness With No Clear Leaders

last_post.content:
Did anyone see this Hallelujah paragraph in the New York Times today? Here's the part we celebrate. (Context is the current melt down of the Republican party...)

"That ideology of destruction defies characterization by traditional political labels like moderate or conservative."

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/05/us/politics/republican-party-leadership.html

Did you hear that? The Times politics desk is now admitting that "conservative" is not a good name for the MAGA forces overtaking the GOP.

And it only took 12 years!

#journalism #uspolitics

title: Twitter Hit With $228.9m Copyright Infringement / Repeat Infringer Lawsuit

last_post.content:
#Twitter may lose its #SafeHarbor protection because it's not responding to #takedown notices for repeat #copyright infringers.
https://torrentfreak.com/twitter-hit-with-228-9m-copyright-infringement-repeat-infringer-lawsuit-230104/

The article doesn't say so, but it seems that Twitter isn't responding to the takedown notices as US law requires ("expeditiously") because of the #Musk layoffs.

This is big. #SocialMedia platforms cannot operate in the US without a safe harbor from copyright lawsuits. It's as if Musk sawed off the wings of his plane to save weight.

title: American Economic Association

last_post.content:
Delighted to be part of this weekend’s #AEA2023 session on the integration and contributions of refugees

If you’re in New Orleans for the American Economic Association meeting do stop by on Sunday morning. Featuring work by Abramitzky, Boustan, Sari & Bill Kerr, Arendt, @petercatron, Mette Foged, Giovanni Peri, and many others

—> https://www.aeaweb.org/conference/2023/program/1227

title: “Tiny Mining”, a Solar Car, and Midnight Creatures Of The Vertical Migration

last_post.content:
"Tiny Mining" is the scientific/artistic movement to extract minerals from human bodies ...

... including developing particular diets so that different minerals will be abundant in your body

Quite wild

Item #5 in my Linkfest here, for Medium subscribers: https://clivethompson.medium.com/tiny-mining-a-solar-car-and-midnight-creatures-of-the-vertical-migration-4f34766343fe

title: https://www.patreon.com/posts/62933244

last_post.content:
​​Taking a step back, the "heroes" of communities that are into pointing out "the world is mad", "X is stupid", etc., seem really into "smarts" and clever solutions and they're explicitly into IQ being important, as in https://www.patreon.com/posts/62933244.

I think this is totally wrong. IMO, having a respect for domain knowledge, domain complexity, meticulously looking at data, etc., is a much more reliable way to find wins as an outsider than being super smart and reasoning from little to no knowledge.

title: Redaction Aesthetics — Are.na

last_post.content: A long time ago I started, then stopped, then re-started this frustrating project on redaction aesthetics that translate across media format + scale (https://www.are.na/shannon-mattern/redaction-aesthetics). Now I’m wondering about artists/ musicians who’ve worked with redacted *sound* — composing with bleeps, sonifying graphic erasures,etc. Thinking of Jamal Cyrus, Susan Philipsz, this: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/19/arts/music/david-little-miller-theater-review.html Might anyone know of other examples? Thx 🙏

title: 95%-ile isn't that good

last_post.content:
Even though they're technically not contradictory, I'm not sure how to reconcile the following two things:

1. Nearly every time an outsider says that people are doing X stupidly and could do way better, they're wrong for boring reasons that are obvious to any insider.

2. It seems fairly easy* to find huge wins as an outsider.

At some level, maybe this is like https://danluu.com/p95-skill/, where the median player in an objective-based game regularly loses because they don't touch the objective, but

title: Moderation

last_post.content:
In preparation for opening datasci.social registrations next week, some news 🚨

1) New mod/admin team: https://community.datasci.social/docs/moderation/ @benfmaier @eflegara @estebanmoro @sdesojo Not a single report so far, but good to be prepared.

2) We adhere to the Mastodon covenant: https://joinmastodon.org/covenant

3) Roadmap: https://community.datasci.social/docs/roadmap/

4) Community pages: https://community.datasci.social/docs, with info on management, moderation, security, server. Check it out! #mastoadmin #serverinfo

Stay tuned for opening news!

title: Your Face Belongs to Us by Kashmir Hill: 9780593448564 | PenguinRandomHouse.com: Books

last_post.content: My book on facial recognition technology comes out on September 19! Over the last two years, I tracked down the tech's early pioneers, found the people fighting against its worst impulses, and dove into the history of Clearview AI, the start-up that first drew me into the topic with a radical person-finding app that giants in the field, including Google and Facebook, had deemed taboo. It feels real now because there's a release date and a preorder button: https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/691288/your-face-belongs-to-us-by-kashmir-hill/

title: DSC Multilingual Mystery #5: Lee & Quinn and the Mystery in the French NLP Model — The Data-Sitters Club

last_post.content:
Starting the new year with a new #DataSittersClub Multilingual Mystery!

Meet "Lee & Quinn and the Mystery in the French NLP Model", where @Readywriting & I try out the #spaCy #French #NLP model on different translations of the Baby-Sitters Club looking for characters as subjects... and find a whole lot less than we expected!

https://datasittersclub.github.io/site/dscm5.html

Also has some handy code if you need to look for verbs associated with characters. #DigitalHumanities

title: github.com/mauforonda/mastodon...

last_post.content:
Look at these great tools by @MattHodges and @mauforonda. They generate regular #digests of popular #mastodon posts from your timeline in case you missed anything. Looking forward to trying them out! 😍

- #python code base: https://github.com/hodgesmr/mastodon_digest
- personal digest page: https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_digest
- email digest: https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_email_digest
- link collector: https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_links

Examples are available from the respective github.io pages.

From: https://hachyderm.io/@mauforonda/109637594948983877

title: European academies hit out at high author charges for open access publishing

last_post.content:
Here's a good article on the #ALLEA recommendations (above).
https://sciencebusiness.net/news/european-academies-hit-out-high-author-charges-open-access-publishing

Quoting Bernt Hugenholtz: "These publishers basically disseminate content that is either completely ready for publication or near-ready for publication…We are moving in the right direction with #openaccess but we have to solve this remuneration problem or, more radically, abandon cooperation with publishers if they are going to keep asking such outrageous publication fees.”

title: Opinion | Want to Understand L.G.B.T.Q. Life in America? Come to Alabama.

last_post.content:
Powerful piece of journalism by Lydia Polgreen for the New York Times. It's in the opinion section, but to me it represents everything opinion ought to be, but rarely is, weaving the story of a math teacher in Alabama who was forced to retire after Libs of TikTok targeted him for also performing as a drag queen into a reflection on where we are, how we got here, and how, as queer people, we need to resist the movement to strip our humanity away.

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/06/opinion/lgbtq-rights-activism-alabama.html
